Award.AwardTitle: Role of Chain Architecture on the Properties of Linear and Star Chain Thin Film Polymer Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL

Interactions at interfaces between polymer surfaces and substrates or the external environment are typically responsible for changes to the local polymer structure, such as monomer "packing" densities and chain organizational order. In polymer films of nanoscale thickness changes to physical properties, including transport properties, average glass transition temperatures, wetting properties and phase stability of blends, are associated with such interactions. Theory and simulations suggest that the interfacial interactions are sensitive to the architecture of the macromolecules. Specifically, star shaped macromolecules exhibit a higher propensity to interact with interfaces. They suffer lower conformational entropic penalties than their linear chain analogs, when adsorbed at interfaces. The goal of this research is to develop an understanding of the role of confinement (thickness and geometrical) and of the macromolecular functionality (number of arms per molecule) of stars on the dynamics, wetting, vitrification, phase equilibra and aging in linear chain/multi-arm star macromolecule blends. The research is accomplished through the use of simulations and complementary experimental tools that include X-ray photon correlation spectroscopy, dielectric spectroscopy, neutron scattering, atomic force microscopy, and transmission electron microscopy techniques.


NON-TECHNICAL

Polymer thin films are used in applications that include protective and functional coatings, active material components in organic electronic devices, and information storage. The performance and reliability of a polymer film is influenced by interactions at interfaces formed between its surfaces and a substrate, or with the external environment. It recently became apparent that the architecture of the polymer molecule, whether it is a linear chain or star-shaped (i.e. more than one chain attached to a central branch point, has a significant impact on the strength of the interfacial interactions. The goal of this project is to understand how the architecture of the polymer molecules, including the number of chains connected to the branch point, affects the physical properties of polymer films. The success of this research will have implications on the use of polymers for wetting and adhesion, protective and functional coatings, and other active technologies. This research will involve a diverse group of collaborators, from high school and undergraduate to graduate students, who will be introduced to research and may become motivated to pursue scientific or technological careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Role of Chain Architecture on the Properties of Thin Film Polymer Systems 

 

 

Thin polymer films are used for diverse applications, including lubrication, adhesion, energy conversion, energy storage, information storage and plastic electronics.  Physical properties, such as diffusion and rheology, of polymers depend on their degrees of polymerization N. Thin polymer films with thicknesses in the nano-sale (nanometers to tens of nanometers) thickness regime exhibit film thickness H dependent properties. Specifically, physical properties (glass transition temperature, mechanical properties and ferroelectric etc.) of polymers deviate from the bulk as the thickness H of the films decreases toward the nanoscale regime –interactions with the external environment largely determine whether the properties increase or decrease in magnitude. Finally, the topology or architecture of a polymeric molecule -linear chain, ring structures or multi-arm stars –can profoundly influence its physical properties. A poorly understood phenomenon of how changing the topology of a macromolecule from a linear-chain to a star (f linear chains connected to a single branch point or node) shaped molecule would lead to changes in physical behavior.

 

One of our most striking discoveries is that the wetting properties, the angle of contact, of a small droplet of a star-shaped macromolecule, varies with the functionality f of the molecule and the degree of polymerization per arm Na! The reason is that this angle is determined by a competition between entropic forces active in these molecules. As f increases from f=2 the molecule suffers a lower entropic (energy) penalty to spread on the surface, hence the decrease in the angle of contact with f.  However as f further increases to larger values these “arms” are forced to stretch (consequence of steric effects); this has the opposite effect -hindering the arms from spreading across the surface.  This contributed to an increase of the effective angle of contact. Because of these competing entropic interactions, the angle of contact varies with f and Na.

 

Entropic effects more strongly influence the packing of star-shaped polymer molecules to fill space than linear-chain polymers. We discovered that the structure of films composed of high functionality stars (f =64) and sufficiently short arms is characterized by single layers of molecules, stacked one on another -similar to a structure of spherical balls that are stacked in layers. These entropic effects become less important when the arms become sufficiently long, as expected. The glass transition temperature Tg of stars is dependent on H, f and Na, due to these entropic interactions. Interestingly Tg is independent of H when f equal to or grater than 64 and Na is small.  The elastic mechanical properties of high functionality thin film star-shaped macromolecules were shown to be larger than those of thin films composed of long-chain and low functionality molecules. The physical aging behavior of these molecules was also investigated. Physical aging refers to the time-dependent changes in physical properties of a glassy material (a substance that has been quenched from elevated temperatures to a temperature below its glass transition temperature) with increasing time. These star-shaped molecules exhibit aging behavior that depends on f and on chain length. The aging rates of star-shaped molecules can be orders of magnitude slower than linear chains. 

 

Finally, these molecules exhibit very rich rheological properties, with changing f. When the arms are long they exhibit linear-viscoelastic behavior. When the arms are short, even for lower functionalities, a different mechanism facilitates flow.  Moreover, the surface dynamics are slow compared to the bulk and the surface glass transition temperatures are high compared to the bulk. The opposite is true for the behavior of linear chain thin film polymers. 

 

The outcomes of this proposal set the foundation for future investigations into the behavior star-shaped based macromolecular systems, including mixtures of linear chain and star-shaped polymers and mixtures of chain-end tethered nanoparticle/polymer mixtures. Overall, our findings have important new implications for the applications of polymers, based on changes in their architectures.
